body: @MaurizioFD I am unable to reproduce this error. Have you modified the code? The loss should be between 0-1 and yours shows 10?

@tebesu Thank you for the reply
I have not modified the code, I have just cloned the repo and executed train.py with the parameters you indicate. The only thing I have done is to create the folder "result".

pretrain.py works fine, I am able to generate a new pretrain npz file and I see a loss value going below 0.01, but still train.py crashes after a few seconds. I have noticed that the error arises in the "# Train Loop" part (lines 96-123). If I comment that part the evaluation of the pretrained model concludes and I see the results for HR and NDCG, they are however in the range of 0.0x.

I have also tried using another pc with ubuntu and a clean installation of tensorflow and sonnet.

@MaurizioFD 

Does the same error occur when you use the provided pretrained model?

@MaurizioFD  @tebesu    
 I also meets the same problems , I am using tensorflow 1.11.0, sonnet 1.23 and python 3.6, 

error is consoled in follow.

I will look into the issue. It runs fine on GPU but throws an error when running on CPU. 

Could @MaurizioFD or @sshzhang confirm running the GPU works fine?

Confronted the same issue while using CPU and problem got resolved after switched to GPU as mentioned by @tebesu. Keen to explore the potential reasons behind if the model performs well on my dataset.

Thanks for reminding me about this issue. @simon19891101 

I refactored the original code used to report the experiments since it was very messy. In the original version I presampled the negative items and stored them in a HD5 file so this issue does not arise in the original version. This version the negatives are sampled on the fly.


The problem stems from calling self.item_users_list[index] which is a defaultdict. In some cases, the index does not exist but still executes the else statement without throwing an exception. 

```
self.item_users_list = defaultdict(list)

# ....

if len(self.item_users[neg_item_idx]) > 0:
    neg_length[idx] = len(self.item_users[neg_item_idx])
    neg_neighbor[idx, :neg_length[idx]] = self.item_users_list[neg_item_idx]
else:
    # Length defaults to 1
    neg_length[idx] = 1
    neg_neighbor[idx, 0] = neg_item_idx
```

I will upload a fix tomorrow.
